awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Yi Liao and J. Clayton Baum of the Department of Chemistry at Florida Institute of Technology are investigating a class of molecules that can reversibly change acid concentrations when irradiated with light.  These molecules, which are called metastable-state photoacids, allow the control of various chemical, biological and material processes with light.  Applications of metastable-state photoacids include photoconductive, photomechanical, photochromic, antibacterial, and drug releasing materials.  The materials can also be used to develop biosensors, microbial fuel cells, and molecular switches.  The mechanisms by which they react, the structure property relationships, and the potential applications of these photoacids are being studied.  The project lies at the interface of organic, photo, physical, biological, and materials chemistry.  The research is well suited for the education of undergraduate and graduate students.  Outreach activities to high school and middle school students are also part of the project activities.     

Numerous chemical, material, and biological processes are sensitive to proton concentration, from acid-catalyzed reactions to activities of many enzymes. Photoacids that reversibly undergo proton dissociation upon irradiation promise remote, spatial and temporal control of acid-sensitive processes.  These compounds could provide a way to convert photoenergy into other types of energy. Although reversible photoacids have been studied, the photoinduced proton concentration change has not been high enough to drive or effectively control  acid sensitive processes.  One major problem in achieving large proton concentration changes is that the lifetime of the high-acidity state is limited by the excited-state lifetime.  To solve this limitation, the investigators couple proton dissociation with a reversible intramolecular photoreactions so that long-lived photoacids can be obtained.  In this approach, the high-acidity state is no longer an excited state, but a metastable state generated from the photoreaction.  Metastable-state photoacids can possess a long-lived high-acidity state and produce a large acidity change under irradiation.  The design of metastable-state photoacids and the photochemical behaviors and mechanisms of these photoacids are being studied both experimentally and theoretically.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Proton transfer is one of the most fundamental processes in nature and numerous chemical, material, and biological processes, e.g. acid catalyzed reactions and enzymatic functions, etc. are driven or affected by protonation. Most proton transfer processes are driven by a high concentration of proton. Our group discovered metastable state photoacid (mPAH), which is reversibly converted to a strong acid under light. MPAHs can reversibly produce a high concentration of proton and allows remote, temporal and spatial control of proton transfer processes by light.

Intellectual merit: In this project, we have systematically examined the structural-property relationship of mPAH, studied the mechanism of the photoreaction, and developed a general approach towards different types of mPAHs with different properties. The results showed that different types of mPAHs possesses different ranges of photo acidity and dark acidity, which make them suitable for different purpose. For example, merocyanine mPAHs are capable of generating a high proton concentration due to high photoacidity, and indazole mPAHs can function in relatively basic conditions due to low dark acidity. The lifetime of the metastable acidic state can be tuned from seconds to hours. For some mPAHs, the reverse process from metastable state to the low-acidity ground state can be accelerated by irradiation with a different wavelength from that of the forward process. MPAHs with novel properties, e.g. near-infrared activity and high C-H photoacidity were discovered.

The photoactivity, reversibility, and chemical stability of mPAHs in water, buffered solutions, organic solvents, and polymer films were carefully studied. MPAHs showed extraordinary photostability, but were slowly hydrolyzed in water. We showed that localized pH pulses can be repeatedly generated using an mPAH polymer even in a pH buffer (PBS). This result is important for biomedical applications since the pH of biological systems are often maintained by pH buffers. Our group also collaborated with other groups to study the mechanism of the mPAH photoreaction using transient absorption spectroscopy, and to develop a novel dissipative assembly, which mimics the natural systems that rely on the input of external energy to control the assembly and disassembly of functional structures on demand.

Broader impact: The mPAHs developed by our group have been used for different chemical, material, energy, biotechnology and biomedical applications by many other researchers, e.g. controlling organic reactions, powering nanoreactors, curing diseases, manipulating DNA and protein, fueling dissipative assemblies, driving molecular machines, developing smart materials and capturing carbon dioxide in air etc.. Six graduate students including two females, who worked on the project, have obtained their PhD degree. The PI has been actively incorporating this research in his class curriculum. He also participated in the InSciEd Out program, which is a national-wide program for rebuilding preK-12 science education curricula in US, and introduced his research to high school teachers.  

Products: This project has resulted in eleven peer-reviewed papers, six PhD dissertations, one book chapter, one patent and a patent amendment, and many presentations in conferences. Some of the works were highlighted in Advanced Science News (Wiley’s online scientific news platform), Journal of Physical Chemistry (cover), and X-mol (the largest online platform of chemistry in China). In addition, we have provided free samples of mPAHs to other researchers who wanted to test mPAHs in their projects.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2021
Modified by: Yi Liao
